Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Market-Based Calibration of Pricing Models for Financial and Energy Option Contracts

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposed research requests funding for the development of high performance computational tools for the fast and accurate calibration of pricing models for financial and energy option contracts using available market data. The results of this research will be used to determine the parameters of various option pricing models that relax the restrictive assumptions of the widely used Black-Scholes-Merton model. For options of the European type, we investigate algorithms for solving optimization problem constrained by discretized partial integro-differential equations. For options of the American type with early exercise features, we develop efficient solution techniques for mathematical programs with complementarity constraints. We also investigate various methods for solving linear complementarity systems arising from the semi-discretization of parabolic variational inequalities for the valuation of American type options.

If successful, the results of the proposed research will lead to the accurate calibration of financial and energy option pricing models, a practical problem that is of fundamental importance to many industrial constituents, including financial firms, pension and mutual fund managers, market participants, energy generators, and commodity producers, who use option contracts as hedging tools to safeguard against large price fluctuations in interest rates, currency exchange rates, equity prices, energy and commodity prices. Improved pricing models in which risks associated with the underlying financial variables are modeled in more appropriate ways will yield better investment decisions and will help reduce arbitrage opportunities and stabilize the financial markets. The results of our research will also benefit the mathematical programming field and other service industries where similar model calibration problems are important.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is on the calibration of derivative securities valuation models using market data. Parameters of a derivatives valuation model are obtained by solving an optimization problem minimizing the difference between model prices and market prices. Such obtained parameters are then used towards new financial or energy derivative contracts to obtain more accurate prices that are consistent with the prices of currently traded derivatives. For a successful calibration, model prices must be computed accurately (forward valuation problem). Then an inverse optimization problem that minimizes the difference between model and market prices needs to be solved efficiently. Depending on the model and derivative type, the forward valuation problem could be approached using methods based on transforms or numerical solution of linear complementarity problems. When linear complementarity problems are used for the forward problem, the inverse optimization problem reduces to mathematical programs with complementarity constraints which are generally large-scale, highly nonlinear and nonconvex.

In this project, we develop efficient numerical methods for solving the forward valuation problem and the inverse optimization problem. For the forward problem, we study the analyticity of the characteristic functions of the probability distributions underlying the models and propose optimal implementation of transform based methods. When characteristic functions are not available, we compute derivative prices by solving parabolic variational inequilities. Discretization leads to linear complementarity problems. We develope splitting methods for fast and accurate solution of the resulting linear complementarity problems. For mathematical programs with complementarity constraints in the inverse problem, we develop approaches that combine implicit programming algorithms, grid method for global optimization, and splitting methods for linear complementarity problems. Numerical experiments show that the above methods are very effective for solving the corresponding forward and inverse problems. Research results that are related to the project have been summarized in published and working papers. They have also been disseminated through conference and seminar talks given by the PIs and graduate students who were involved in the project. Some of the research results have been incorporated into courses the PIs teach. Both the students in the courses and the graduate students who were directly involved in the project benefit from it. They will be able to apply the theory and methods they learned to their future research or for solving similar practical problems they encounter in their career. Transforms, linear complementarity problems and mathematical programs with complementarity constraints often arise in other applications in engineering and science. Findings of the project not only could be used for solving derivatives valuation and calibration problems in financial engineering, but also could be used for solving similar problems that arise in other disciplines.

Derivative securities play a very important role in today's world. The size of the global over-the-counter derivatives market by the end of December 2014 was about $630 trillion. Corporations and fund managers use derivatives to hedge risks they face due to the fluctuation of interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates, equity, commodity and energy prices. Results from this project might help them to make better financial decisions when managing their hedging portfolios and help to maintain a more stable financial market.
